prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue

data.expected: Bt x BT -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BT, 1/4 TT

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green

options: BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG

data.sampled: This is not possible in a monohybrid inheritance system with three alleles. The genotype of the parents would have to be BB, and the genotype of the offspring would have to be B_. However, in a homozygous dominant trait, the offspring would always inherit the dominant trait and would not have a recessive trait to pass on to the next generation. Therefore, it is impossible for the offspring to be pure dominant in a monohybrid inheritance system.
